newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey says sugar processing plans depend on price.
newsitem.headline: Turkey says sugar processing plans depend on price.

text.p: Turkey's plans to turn two more of its white sugar production plants into raws processors depend mainly on the difference between whites and raws prices on international markets.

"If the price difference between raws and whites is more than $100 (per tonne), then the conversion of the refineries into raw sugar processing units can be justified," said a senior official from state refiner Turkseker.
"But recently the difference have been around $80 excluding freight and other costs, and that does not justify the investment at this stage," he told Reuters.
Turkseker, which operates 25 of the 28 sugar refineries in Turkey, had plans to convert refineries in Adapazari and Susurluk, two western provinces where beet production is diminishing.
But officials later suspended the plan because of financial problems.

The official said the other factor to be considered in planning was white sugar production, which had risen to 1.85 million tonnes in 1996/97 from 1.5 million a year earlier. Beet producers expect it to rise to 2.05 million tonnes in 1997/98.
"We have a better output this year. So we may not need the plants for some time," he said.
Turkey turned its Carsamba refinery on the Black Sea into a raws unit in 1995 with a daily processing capacity of 500 tonnes to produce whites from imported raws.
The plant's output was meant for export. Turkseker has exported 12,500 tonnes of its output so far.
The official said the Adapazari plant, the first one on the agenda, would be able to process 900 tonnes of raws a day if it became operational.
"The cost of converting one plant is not much. It is something like 100 billion lira," he said.
